description.narrative: BNP Paribas Commodity Futures Limited (CFL) provides investment business services in the United Kingdom. It trades commodity futures including electricity, emissions, natural gas, carbon, coal, freight, oil, bio fuels, and metals, as well as soft commodities, including coffee, sugar, cocoa, and grain products such as wheat, corn and soybean. The company was incorporated in 1989 and is based in London, the United Kingdom. CFL operates as a subsidiary of BNP Paribas and is part of BNP Paribas Commodity Derivatives unit that has branches and subsidiaries all over the world The proposed 3 or 4 years transaction consists of up to US$100 million of un-funded IFC risk participation (the Facility or the Project) in a portfolio of margin financing facilities provided by BNPP to clients such as agricultural commodities traders, producers and consumers. This risk participation will support further growth in CFL clients activities in emerging markets.

The key development impacts are: - Improved Access to Finance: By indirectly enabling emerging markets farmers and agricultural intermediaries across several countries to obtain price risk management products, the Project will facilitate their access to finance (since their lenders will be less exposed to factor price risk into their funding decisions). - Relieve EM producers, consumers and intermediaries from the negative impact of margin calls on the liquidity position - Increased Agricultural Production: Better access to finance for producers can be expected to lead to increased agriculture production, which in turn will have a positive effect on agriculture prices. - More Stable Markets for agri-commodity Products: It is expected to enable producers, intermediaries and consumers of agri-products to enter into more stable and longer term contracts, lowering uncertainty and improving price stability/help address price volatility. The Project will support agribusiness in emerging markets by increasing the volume of trades executed on exchanges for the EM producers, consumers and intermediaries.
